title: 108_hr1874
content: The Act titled the "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" clarifies the definition of homebound through a demonstration project. The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" establishes a demonstration project where Medicare beneficiaries with chronic conditions can receive home health services if they meet specific criteria, regardless of their ability to leave home. The Secretary will collect data on a demonstration project for home health services to Medicare beneficiaries, focusing on quality of care, patient outcomes, and costs to the Medicare program. Reports to Congress will be submitted one year after implementation and again one year later. The Secretary has the authority to waive compliance with certain requirements to conduct demonstration projects, without waiving any applicable penalties or remedies under title XI or XVIII. The Secretary is authorized to appropriate funds from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Insurance Trust Fund for a demonstration project on home health services for Medicare beneficiaries. Definitions for "Medicare beneficiary," "home health services," and "activities of daily living" are provided in this section. The term "activities of daily living" includes eating, toileting, transferring, bathing, and dressing. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Clarification of the definition of homebound for determining eligibility for home health services under the Medicare program. The Social Security Act is amended to allow individuals with permanent severe conditions requiring assistance with daily activities to qualify as 'confined to home' for Medicare home health services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress by December 1, 2006, analyzing the impact of a demonstration project on home health services under Medicare. If the report does not find adverse effects or unreasonable cost increases, the project will be discontinued, and amendments will take effect on January 1, 2007. The Secretary must include specific data and recommendations in the report regarding the increase in expenditures and exemptions for permanently and severely disabled homebound beneficiaries from restrictions on home health services. Additionally, technical amendments are made to sections of the Social Security Act. The sixth sentence is modified to include "leave home and". Section 1814(a) of the Social Security Act is amended by moving the seventh sentence to the end of the section.
